DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Nu Barred from Elections
Eds: One name correct for Nu
DOC.TEXT: The ruling military junta has barred Burma's last democratically elected prime minister from running in the May general elections, the government said Friday. Kyaw Sann, spokesman for the military rulers, said former Prime Minister Nu was disqualified for his refusal to dissolve a parallel government he declared at the height of last year's national uprising for democracy. The spokesman told a weekly official news briefing that Nu also would face legal action, but that he would not be imprisoned. Nu announced his 26-member government Sept. 9, 1988, saying he was still the country's rightful prime minister because the 1962 military coup that ousted him was illegal. Gen. Saw Maung's State Law and Order Restoration Council seized power and brutally crushed protests nine days after Nu declared his government. Saw Maung declared the rival Cabinet illegal and demanded its dissolution as a condition for Nu to run in the election scheduled for May 27. The election will be the first multiparty balloting in Burma since Nu was elected in 1960. But diplomats say the military junta has arrested and harassed thousands of dissidents since it seized power, raising doubts the election will be free and fair. At a Christmas Day news conference, the 82-year-old Nu rejected the government demand, saying he was ``prepared to face any consequences.'' In a Dec. 7 letter to Saw Maung, Nu said he would disband his government only when Ne Win, the general who ousted him, made a public apology. Kyaw Sann said members of Nu's party who were part of his government and refused to disown it also were barred from the elections. But those who withdrew from the parallel government would be allowed to run, even if they remained members of Nu's League for Democracy and Peace, he said. In reply to a reporter's question, Kyaw Sann said Aung San Suu Kyi, considered the most popular opposition figure, would be allowed to run providing she did not violate any provisions of the election law. Ms. Suu Kyi has been under house arrest since July 20, accused of trying to divide the people from the army. A week ago, Gen. Tin Oo, chairman of her National League for Democracy party, was sentenced to three years in prison on the same charge.
